title: Coordinate Transformations in gggenes
text: gggenes supports three coordinate systems: Cartesian, flipped (coord_flip()), polar (coord_polar()). Rather writing separate geometry logic , package uses abstraction called “along/away”: Along: direction along molecule backbone Away: direction perpendicular backbone maps different axes depending coordinate system: abstraction, geometry can defined along/away terms transformed appropriately coordinate system. following diagram illustrates full transformation pipeline coordinate system:

what: Important: Along/Away Are Not Always NPC
title: Coordinate Transformations in gggenes
text: key subtlety along/away values represent different things depending coordinate system: Cartesian/Flipped: Along away NPC (normalised parent coordinates), scaled 0-1. transformation data NPC happens via coord$transform() complete point. Polar: Along theta (radians, 0 2π) away r (radius, scaled 0–0.5). NPC—’re polar coordinates still need converted Cartesian NPC grid draw. means data--NPC transformation happens different stages:
code: Cartesian: data → coord$transform() → NPC (stored as along/away) → grid Polar:     data → coord$transform() → θ/r (stored as along/away) → trig conversion → NPC → grid

title: Coordinate Transformations in gggenes
text: encapsulate complexity, gggenes uses compose_grob() function handles entire transformation pipeline raw data final grob. function: Detects coordinate system Transforms data along/away coordinates Converts unit measurements (mm, etc.) along/away values Calls geometry function transformed values Segments geometry polar coordinates (curves appear smooth) Converts along/away grid NPC coordinates Creates returns appropriate grob

title: Coordinate Transformations in gggenes
text: Geometry defined regular R function receives data row transformed coordinates, returns polygon polyline vertices: function receives standard interface: data_row: single-row data frame transformed coordinates. Contains along (point geoms) along_min/along_max (range geoms), plus away. subgene geoms, also contains along_submin/along_submax. gt: gTree object containing geom-specific parameters grid::unit() objects (e.g., gt$arrowhead_width). as_along: Function convert grid::unit() native along-units. as_away: Function convert grid::unit() native away-units. coordinate values data_row already transformed along/away space. geometry function converts unit measurements needed using converter functions.
code: gene_arrow_geometry <- function(data_row, gt, as_along, as_away) {   # Extract transformed coordinates from data_row   along_min <- data_row$along_min   along_max <- data_row$along_max   away <- data_row$away    # Convert units using the converter functions   arrowhead_along <- as_along(gt$arrowhead_width)   arrowhead_away <- as_away(gt$arrowhead_height)   body_away <- as_away(gt$arrow_body_height)    # Compute intermediate values   orientation <- ifelse(along_max > along_min, 1, -1)   arrowhead_along_clamped <- ifelse(     arrowhead_along > abs(along_max - along_min),     abs(along_max - along_min),     arrowhead_along   )   flange <- along_max - orientation * arrowhead_along_clamped   arrowhead_away_half <- arrowhead_away / 2   body_away_half <- body_away / 2    # Return vertex coordinates   list(     alongs = c(along_min, along_min, flange, flange, along_max, flange, flange),     aways = c(       away + body_away_half,       away - body_away_half,       away - body_away_half,       away - arrowhead_away_half,       away,       away + arrowhead_away_half,       away + body_away_half     )   ) }

code: # Inside compose_grob(): as_along <- if (coord_system == "cartesian") {    function(unit) as.numeric(grid::convertWidth(unit, "native")) } else if (coord_system == "polar") {   function(unit) as.numeric(grid::convertWidth(unit, "native")) / r } else if (coord_system == "flip") {   function(unit) as.numeric(grid::convertHeight(unit, "native")) }  as_away <- if (coord_system == "cartesian") {   function(unit) as.numeric(grid::convertHeight(unit, "native")) } else if (coord_system == "polar") {   function(unit) as.numeric(grid::convertHeight(unit, "native")) } else if (coord_system == "flip") {   function(unit) as.numeric(grid::convertWidth(unit, "native")) }

title: Coordinate Transformations in gggenes
text: ggplot2 draws polar-coordinate plots defining Cartesian coordinates passed grid. Grid doesn’t know ’s drawing polar-coordinate plot. Hence, straight line polar-coordinate plot defined line two points, drawn straight chord rather arc. make lines follow polar geometry, must broken many small segments conversion Cartesian coordinates. ggplot2, known ‘munching’. segmentation handled automatically compose_grob(). segmentation algorithm works follows: pair consecutive vertices (wrap-around polygons), calculate “length” polar space: sqrt((Δr)² + (Δθ)²) Create round(length * 100) segments vertices—approximately 100 segments per unit combined polar distance Linearly interpolate r θ create intermediate points polylines, algorithm respects id groupings keep separate line segments separate Note compose_grob() includes handling special case theta wraps around 0/2π. range geom’s endpoint transforms exactly 0 radians logically 2π (based original data ordering), value corrected. However, geometries truly span across 0/2π boundary (e.g., 350° 10°) currently supported need split two separate geometries.

title: Coordinate Transformations in gggenes
text: geometry computed along/away space, ’s converted grid x/y: polar, standard polar--Cartesian conversion, centered (0.5, 0.5) viewport.
code: if (coord_system == "cartesian") {   x <- alongs   y <- aways } else if (coord_system == "polar") {   x <- 0.5 + aways * sin(alongs)   y <- 0.5 + aways * cos(alongs) } else if (coord_system == "flip") {   x <- aways   y <- alongs }

title: Coordinate Transformations in gggenes
text: architecture: draw_panel() minimal; just packages data, coord, panel_scales gTree makeContent() defines units geometry() function, iterates data rows calling compose_grob() compose_grob() encapsulates coordinate transformation pipeline, independent geometry individual geom makes straightforward add new geoms: define geometry function unit specifications, call compose_grob() appropriate grob type. Currently, compose_grob() supports three grob types: "polygon": Creates closed polygon using grid::polygonGrob() "polyline": Creates open line(s) using grid::polylineGrob(), optional id vector multiple segments arrow parameter arrowheads "text": Creates text label using ggfittext. geometry function returns bounding box (along_min, along_max, away_min, away_max) instead vertices. Text styling (fontface, colour, etc.) comes data_row columns rather gp parameter

title: Coordinate Transformations in gggenes
code: makeContent.genearrowtree <- function(x) {   data <- x$data    # Define geometry function with standard interface   geometry <- function(data_row, gt, as_along, as_away) {     # Extract transformed coordinates     along_min <- data_row$along_min     along_max <- data_row$along_max     away <- data_row$away      # Convert units     arrowhead_along <- as_along(gt$arrowhead_width)     arrowhead_away <- as_away(gt$arrowhead_height)     body_away <- as_away(gt$arrow_body_height)      # Compute geometry     orientation <- ifelse(along_max > along_min, 1, -1)     arrowhead_along_clamped <- ifelse(       arrowhead_along > abs(along_max - along_min),       abs(along_max - along_min),       arrowhead_along     )     flange <- along_max - orientation * arrowhead_along_clamped     arrowhead_away_half <- arrowhead_away / 2     body_away_half <- body_away / 2      list(       alongs = c(         along_min,         along_min,         flange,         flange,         along_max,         flange,         flange       ),       aways = c(         away + body_away_half,         away - body_away_half,         away - body_away_half,         away - arrowhead_away_half,         away,         away + arrowhead_away_half,         away + body_away_half       )     )   }    # Prepare grob for each gene   grobs <- lapply(seq_len(nrow(data)), function(i) {     gene <- data[i, ]      # Reverse non-forward genes     if (!as.logical(gene$forward)) {       gene[, c("xmin", "xmax")] <- gene[, c("xmax", "xmin")]     }      # Set up graphical parameters     gp <- grid::gpar(       fill = ggplot2::alpha(gene$fill, gene$alpha),       col = ggplot2::alpha(gene$colour, gene$alpha),       lty = gene$linetype,       lwd = gene$linewidth * ggplot2::.pt     )      compose_grob(       geometry_fn = geometry,       gt = x,       data_row = gene,       grob_type = "polygon",       gp = gp     )   })    class(grobs) <- "gList"   grid::setChildren(x, grobs) }

title: Introduction to 'gggenes'
text: geom_gene_arrow() ‘ggplot2’ geom represents genes arrows. start end locations genes within molecule(s) mapped xmin xmax aesthetics respectively. start end locations used determine directions arrows point. y aesthetic must mapped molecule(s). drawing one molecule, numerical locations genes similar across molecules, almost certainly want facet plot scales = "free" avoid drawing ridiculously large molecules ridiculously tiny genes.
code: library(ggplot2) library(gggenes) ggplot(example_genes, aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y = molecule, fill = gene)) +   geom_gene_arrow() +   facet_wrap(~ molecule, scales = "free", ncol = 1) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set3")
